When Korematsus case reached the Supreme Court in October 1944 the attorneys for the government pointed to the constitutional war powers of Congress and the president. The government argued that the military must take all steps necessary to wage war successfully. In the view of President Roosevelt the War Department and General DeWitt the internment of all Japanese Issei and Nisei was a military necessity. and assuming we were at war with ISIS then rounding up ISIS would not be racist On December 18 1944 the Supreme Court decided 63 to uphold the conviction of Korematsu. The majority ruled only on his refusal to leave a prohibited military area and did not consider the constitutionality of the relocation camps. Justice Hugo Black writing for the majority fully accepted the views of General DeWitt. Justice Black also said that Korematsu had not been forced from his home because of his race but because of the military urgency of the situation. http://www.crf-usa.org/america-responds-to-terrorism/wartime-and-the-bill-of-rights.html http://www.crf-usa.org/america-responds-to-terrorism/wartime-and-the-bill-of-rights.html

I love when ignorant Europeans love to cite the fact that the majority of the refugees are not from Syria as though this is some kind of fallacy in the argument for letting them come in.. The economies of a lot of north African/other Middle East states are shit and many of these people are simply economic refugees.. That part of the world is experiencing environmental stessors that are causing droughts which damage the land's carrying capacity and this obviously also affects the economy; all of this contributes to the people there wanting to move to literally greener pastures.. The history of the world is nothing but people migrating through time.. Modern Europe went through so much demographic shifts over the centuries.. This is nothing new.. The Huns apparently originated somewhere in or around Mongolia and began their westward trek after being oppressed by a rival ethnic group that came to power.. and so they decided to migrate thousands of miles to the west.. Undoubtedly I am sure their ethnic makeup changed during this travel as they picked up some and lost others before reaching Europe.. But still modern Europe USA and the world has been nothing but a melting pot of people on the move forever.. This xenophobia thing is an interesting illusion.. However I will defend that 'us vs them' mentality when there is a legitimate aggressor and oppressee(i guess that is how one would state that..). For example; the Inca revolt against the Conquistadors.. On another note.. well that is enough for now.. I could ramble on for hours on the nature of group identities in a world of shifting populations.. I'll write up a paper fleshing out my thoughts on the whole subject someday; all sides and viewpoints need to have their feet up to the fire so to speak..

I really wish commentators would stop using terms like 'equal rights' to talk about gay marriage. It has nothing to do with equality and everything to do with social change. For example here in the UK prior to the passage of the law legalising same sex marriage in 2012 we had a system of parallel but essentially equal frameworks. Marriage was defined as being between a man and a woman but 'civil partnerships' existed that were essentially equal in terms of rights and benefits and could only be entered into by gay people. For those who compare this situation to US racial segregation look at your argument. Racial segregation was so unfair because the races were not 'separate but equal'. They were separate but unequal. As long as there is legal equality I do not see any issue of equality with a society democratically saying it wants to use one term for heterosexual relationships and another for same sex relationships.
